David wrote:

> The developers in the project I am currently working changed their private 
> methods to public just to UNIT test their code. It is currently very 
> important to test the private methods as it accounts for over 60% of the 
> functionality and logic. I have found that enables me to test bottom up and 
> I have more confidence when coding and when I need to refactor.


It the code isn't tested through the public (or protected) then you 
aren't testing it in the context in which it will actually be used. 
Private methods are always invoked through the published APIs. This may 
have effects or implications that are not seen when testing the private 
methods directly.

Furthermore, the logic you're testing in the private APIs may not be 
reachable from the public APIs, in which case it can be eliminated.
